channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Russia Douses Trump’s Eagerness for Pope to Host Ukraine Talks
item.description: The US and European leaders are placing their hopes in the Vatican to engage Russia and Ukraine in peace talks, after President Donald Trump said Pope Leo XIV had expressed interest in the idea. The Kremlin isn’t so keen.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Pope Leo XIV at St Peter's Square in The Vatican on May 21.

item.title: Trump’s Next Hurdle: The Bond Market Hates His ‘Beautiful’ Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump cut a deal with blue-state Republicans on taxes and put down an 11th-hour rebellion by conservatives over spending to get his “one big, beautiful bill” passed by the House.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Liz Capo McCormick, Nancy Cook

item.title: UK to Pay Mauritius £101 Million a Year to Use Military Base
item.description: The UK agreed to cede an Indian Ocean archipelago to Mauritius while retaining control of a strategic military base on one of the islands, ending a long-running negotiation that had become a point of controversy for British premier Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Kamlesh Bhuckory, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Diego Garcia

item.title: RFK Jr. Report Blames Diet, Overmedication for Chronic Diseases
item.description: The Trump administration issued a report blaming the rise in chronic diseases in the US on unhealthy food ingredients, chemicals, overreliance on medication and corporate spending. But it stopped short of attacking growers and manufacturers as much as they feared.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

item.title: EU Has Begun Lifting Measures Imposed on Kosovo, Kallas Says
item.description: The European Union has started to “gradually lift” punitive measures imposed on Kosovo, the bloc’s foreign-affairs chief Kaja Kallas said.
item.dc:creator: Gresa Kraja, Max Ramsay

media:content.media:description: Kaja Kallas

item.title: Putin Says Russia Creating Buffer Zone Along Ukrainian Border
item.description: Russia has started to create a buffer zone along its border with Ukraine as the Kremlin continues efforts to strengthen defenses in neighboring regions against attacks.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: Russian soldiers ride in a car in the Kursk region.

item.title: ECB Says Water Is Top Nature-Related Risk to European Economy
item.description: Water has emerged as the single biggest nature-related risk to euro area economy, according to the European Central Bank and researchers at the University of Oxford.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort

media:content.media:description: An irrigation machine in a field near the Po river in the San Rocco al Porto near Piacenza, Italy, on Thursday, June 16, 2022. The Po river, that crosses Italy’s north horizontally, is at the lowest levels in 70 years and the drought is threatening crops.

item.title: South Africa Expects US Reset Despite White House Confrontation
item.description: South Africa’s finance chief said the government made progress on resetting its relationship with the US and securing a trade deal in talks that took place after President Cyril Ramaphosa’s showdown with Donald Trump at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Oil License to End, in Setback for Chevron
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said in a post on X that a Venezuela oil-export license will expire next Tuesday, defying earlier expectations that it would be extended.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Crayton Harrison

media:content.media:description: A worker passes signage at the Chevron Corp. offices in Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday, Dec. 1, 2022. The Biden administration granted Chevron a license to resume oil production in Venezuela after US sanctions halted all drilling activities almost three years ago. Photographer: Matias Delacroix/Bloomberg

item.title: New Jersey ‘Sanctuary Cities’ Sued by Trump Administration Over Immigration Policies
item.description: The US sued four “sanctuary cities” in New Jersey, claiming they are blocking the work of federal immigration officials, as the Trump administration seeks to remove obstacles to its mass deportation plans.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: Newark, New Jersey.

item.title: Google Faces Antitrust Investigation Over Deal for AI-Fueled Chatbots
item.description: The Justice Department is probing whether Alphabet Inc.’s Google violated antitrust law with an agreement to use the artificial intelligence technology of a popular chatbot maker, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Josh Sisco

media:content.media:description: The Google campus in Mountain View, California.

item.title: Supreme Court Deadlocks in Loss for Religious Charter School
item.description: The US Supreme Court divided evenly in a major case over the separation of religion and government, thwarting an effort in Oklahoma to create the nation’s first faith-based charter school.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Senate Votes to End California Gas-Car Ban, Sends Bill to Trump
item.description: The US Senate voted to block a California program banning gasoline-powered cars and other vehicles by 2035, sending the measure to President Donald Trump’s desk for his signature.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Traffic moves along Interstate 80 in Emeryville, California.

item.title: North Korean Warship Seen Severely Damaged After Failed Launch
item.description: North Korea has placed a cover over a destroyer that suffered damage in a botched launch attempt, with the vessel now appearing to be on its side and partially submerged, satellite imagery indicates.
item.dc:creator: Jon Herskovitz

media:content.media:description: A satellite image shows blue tarps covering a North Korean destroyer in Chongjin Shipyard, North Korea, on May 22.

item.title: California Politicians Push 13-Bill Package to Rescue Downtowns
item.description: A group of California mayors and Assembly members unveiled a sweeping legislative package aimed at rescuing the state’s downtowns from the lingering economic effects of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Alicia Clanton

media:content.media:description: The California State Capitol building in Sacramento.

item.title: France, Saudi Arabia Aim to Disarm Hamas in New Peace Push
item.description: France and Saudi Arabia are working on a proposal to disarm the Iran-backed militant group Hamas, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Sam Dagher, Samy Adghirni, Fiona MacDonald

media:content.media:description: Palestinian protesters with a "Stop War" sign during a demonstration against the Hamas militant group in Beit Lahiya, northern Gaza, on March 26.

item.title: Trump Floats a Public Offering for Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac
item.description: President Donald Trump said that he’s giving “very serious consideration to bringing Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac public” after more than a decade of government control.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Clark, Scott Carpenter, John Harney

media:content.media:description: Signage outside the Freddie Mac headquarters in Mclean, Virginia, US, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. The head of the US Federal Housing Finance Agency on Tuesday ordered to end Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac programs intended to support first-time homebuyers by providing down payments and closing cost assistance. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: Fringe White Afrikaners Show How Lobbying Trump Can Work
item.description: The fringe group that planted the seed for some of Donald Trump’s false claims that South Africa is persecuting White farmers saw years of lobbying US politicians pay off.
item.dc:creator: Rene Vollgraaff

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump shows pictures as he meets with Cyril Ramaphosa in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 21.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Faces Senate’s Arcane Rules, Desire for Changes
item.description: The Republican legislative balancing act now shifts to the Senate.
item.dc:creator: Lillianna Byington, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune, a Republican from South Dakota, during a news conference following the Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. A bipartisan alliance backing stablecoin legislation shattered in the US Senate as a key group of Democrats threatened to block a bill that Republicans had hoped to pass this month, unless "numerous" fixes are made.

item.title: Russia Faces Massive, Two-Day Drone Attack That Disrupts Flights
item.description: Russia said its air defenses downed 485 Ukrainian drones over a period of two days, a sustained attack that delayed more than 100 flights as airports around Moscow temporarily halted operations.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: The Kremlin, Moscow.

item.title: G-7 Draft Warns of ‘Excessive Imbalances’ in Global Economy
item.description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven nations pledged to address “excessive imbalances” in the global economy, an effort clearly aimed at China, though a draft communique seen by Bloomberg News omitted the name of the country.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Jorge Valero, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Hochul Digs In on Toll, Risking Federal Funds for NYC Plans
item.description: Transportation projects in Manhattan may be at risk of losing federal approval or funds after New York Governor Kathy Hochul rejected the Trump administration’s demand to end congestion pricing.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: Kathy Hochul on the uptown E train after a news conference on congestion pricing in New York on March 21.

item.title: Why South Africa’s Land Law Is at Heart of Trump Row
item.description: Land ownership remains an explosive issue in South Africa more than three decades after White-minority rule ended. It’s also at the center of a diplomatic row with the US, as President Donald Trump and his Pretoria-born billionaire ally Elon Musk falsely claim that the South African government is engaging in land grabs and that there’s a genocide against White Afrikaner farmers.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Cyril Ramaphosa and Donald Trump Source: Bloomberg

item.title: Polish Presidential Hopeful Says Opposes Ukraine Joining NATO
item.description: Poland’s opposition candidate for president, Karol Nawrocki, said he won’t support NATO membership for Ukraine and is “more critical” than the incumbent toward Kyiv, as he seeks to court far-right voters ahead of a runoff in a closely-contested election.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: GDANSK, POLAND - MAY 18: Karol Nawrocki, a non-partisan Presidential candidate supported by the right wing Law and Justice Party reacts after first exit polls results with his family; wife Marta and daughter Katarzyna, during the presidential election night on May 18, 2025 in Gdansk, Poland. The election is seen as a test of whether the government, with its centrist parliamentary coalition, can overcome the right-wing populism embodied by the Law and Justice Party, which has held the presidency since 2015. Exit polls give 30.8 % for Rafal Trzaskowski and 29.1% for Karol Nawrodzki. (Photo by Wojciech Grzedzinski/Getty Images)

item.title: Trump’s R&D Funding Cuts Create Job Drought for Scientists
item.description: US job openings in research and development are plunging as the Trump administration ramps up funding cuts to government agencies, private contractors and universities, leaving some of the nation’s brightest minds scrambling to find work.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Leon Black's Son Brings Wall Street Vibe to US Foreign Investment Agency
item.description: Ben Black has no formal experience working in Washington and a limited Wall Street resume. Yet the son of billionaire Apollo Global Management Inc. co-founder Leon Black is now set to run an agency with a growing role in White House policy — the US International Development Finance Corp.
item.dc:creator: Loukia Gyftopoulou, Joe Deaux, Marion Halftermeyer

media:content.media:description: Ben Black at the Milken Institute Global Conference in Beverly Hills in 2022.

item.title: Macron Talks Up China Ties and Touts Progress on Cognac
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron is seeking to deepen economic ties with China as the European Union adjusts to the twin shocks of the American trade war and the continuing Russian invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James Regan, Angelina Rascouet

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, right, and Xi Jinping in Paris in 2024.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Narrowly Passes House, Overcoming Infighting
item.description: President Donald Trump’s signature tax bill narrowly passed the House Thursday morning, advancing a sprawling multi-trillion dollar package that would avert a year-end tax increase at the expense of adding to the US debt burden.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Erik Wasson, Maeve Sheehey

item.title: Poland Says Key Infrastructure at Risk After Baltic Sea Incident
item.description: Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk warned on Thursday that the Baltic Sea is becoming “a new area of confrontation” with Russia, putting the country’s critical infrastructure increasingly at risk.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Bujnicki

media:content.media:description: Donald Tusk

item.title: Germany Vows to Defend Baltics Against Any Russian Threat
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz said Germany’s military is prepared to defend the Baltic region against “any threat” as he arrived in Lithuania to mark the establishment of a battle tank brigade aimed at bolstering NATO’s eastern flank.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz and Gitanas Nauseda, left, during a welcoming ceremony in Vilnius, Lithuania, on May 22. Photographer: Paulius Peleckis/Getty Images
